%spark.pyspark

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import pyspark.ml as ml
import matplotlib.pylab as plt
from collections import Counter
import pyspark.sql.functions as f
from pyspark.ml.feature import VectorAssembler
from pyspark.sql.functions import lit, col, when, floor
from pyspark.ml.classification import MultilayerPerceptronClassifier
from pyspark.ml.evaluation import MulticlassClassificationEvaluator

user_home = 'file:///user/dcr/'

%spark.pyspark
# from mllib_results import MLlib_confusion_matrix, MLlibMultiClassEvaluator, plottingThreshold

%spark.pyspark

# define the data source

pmdec, pmdec_error, pmra_error, astrometric_excess\
_noise ,visibility_periods_used, ruwe, astrometric_gof_al,\
ipd_gof_harmonic_amplitude, ipd_frac_odd_win, ipd_frac_multi_peak, phot_g_mean_mag, phot_rp_mean_mag, g_rp'

paragraphs.title: Collect Required Data
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
# clear any previously cached data in the context (cells may be executed in any order, and out-dated by changes from here onwards)
sqlContext.clearCache()

# Select all data
raw_sources_df = spark.sql(f'SELECT {columns} \
 FROM gaia_source')
#  WHERE (1/parallax < 1)')
# cache it for speedy access below (all subsequent samples are derived from this):
# raw_sources_cached = raw_sources_df.cache()
# ... some good advice concerning caching in Spark here: https://towardsdatascience.com/best-practices-for-caching-in-spark-sql-b22fb0f02d34

# register as SQL-queryable
raw_sources_df.createOrReplaceTempView('dcr_raw_sources')
del raw_sources_df
# raw_sources_df.count()
# EDR3: 1,055,241,799 sources in XXmin XXsec (<3 kpcs)
# EDR3: 574,486,895 sources in 00min 02sec (<1 kpcs)
# EDR3: 357,995,072 sources in 00min 02sec (<0.1 kpcs)

paragraphs.title: Show CAMD Unsorted
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

def CAMD(passbands, catalogues, colors = ["k", 'darkred', 'darkblue'], ms = 1, labels = None, limit = 10000):
    """plot an observational Hertzsprung-Russell diagram (aka colour / absolute magnitude diagram)
    for the unclassified sample to show the problem,
    include the photometric consistency filter to show the problem is astrometric in addition to photometric"""
    
    import matplotlib.pylab as plt
    fig = plt.figure(0, figsize = (9.0, 9.0))
    c = -1

    for i in catalogues:
        c+=1
        if type(ms) == list:
            s = ms[c]
        else: s = ms
        if type(labels) == type(None):
            label = i
        else: label = labels[c]
        dat = spark.sql(f"SELECT phot_{passbands[0]}_mean_mag + 5.0*LOG10(parallax/100.0) AS m_{passbands[0]}, {passbands[1]} FROM {i} WHERE parallax > 0  LIMIT {limit}")
        dat = dat.select(["g_rp", "m_g"]).toPandas()
        plt.scatter(dat['g_rp'], -dat['m_g'], marker = '.', s = s, c = colors[c], label = label)
    # plt.ylim(21.0, -3.0)
    plt.ylabel("Stellar brightness (absolute G magnitude) -->", fontsize = 16)
    plt.xlabel("<-- Stellar temperature (G - RP magnitude)", fontsize = 16)
    lgnd = plt.legend(fontsize = 12, markerscale = 1)
    for i in range(len(catalogues)):
        lgnd.legendHandles[i]._sizes = [25]

CAMD(passbands = ["g", "g_rp"], catalogues = ["dcr_raw_sources"], colors = ["k"], limit = 25000, labels = ['All Sources'])

paragraphs.title: Get HEALPix-6 Factor

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Sort *'Labelled'* Training Data

- Good data = each HEALPix level-6 pixel that contains no sources with parallax_over_error < −3.5.
- Bad data = parallax_over_error < −4.5

### With further split into SNR bins

* High SNR = parallax_over_error (SNR) > 4.5
* Low SNR = -3.5 < SNR < 4.5

msg.data:
Sort ‘Labelled’ Training Data

  • Good data = each HEALPix level-6 pixel that contains no sources with parallax_over_error < −3.5.
  • Bad data = parallax_over_error < −4.5

With further split into SNR bins

  • High SNR = parallax_over_error (SNR) > 4.5
  • Low SNR = -3.5 < SNR < 4.5

paragraphs.title: Define features
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

factor = healpix_level_N(source_id = None, level = 6, constant = True)

def getFeatures(withPhotometric = False):
    # select features to use
    features = [
        'source_id', 'parallax_error', 'parallax_over_error',
        'pmra', 'astrometric_sigma5d_max', 'pmdec',
        'pmdec_error', 'pmra_error', 'astrometric_excess_noise',
        'visibility_periods_used', 'ruwe', 'astrometric_gof_al',
        'ipd_gof_harmonic_amplitude', 'ipd_frac_odd_win', 'ipd_frac_multi_peak',]
        
    if withPhotometric:
        features.extend(['m_g', 'g_rp'])
    
    return features

features = getFeatures()

paragraphs.title: Select Good or Bad Sources
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

def select_bad_sources(table):
    '''Selects bad sources from eDR3'''
    
    bad = spark.sql(f'SELECT a.* \
                    FROM {table} as a\
                    WHERE parallax_over_error < -4.5')
    # print(f'{bad.count()} bad sources')
    print(f'Collected bad sources')
    
    return bad

def select_good_sources(table):
    '''Selects good sources from eDR3'''
    
    good = spark.sql(f'SELECT a.* \
    FROM {table} as a \
    WHERE (a.parallax_over_error > 4.5 AND (a.phot_g_mean_mag - a.phot_rp_mean_mag) <1.8) \
    OR (a.parallax_over_error < 4.5 AND a.parallax_over_error > -3.0 AND \
    (a.phot_g_mean_mag - a.phot_rp_mean_mag) <1.5)')
    # print(f'{good.count()} good sources')
    print(f'Collected Good sources')
    return good

def with_flags(table, features = "*"):
    '''Collects data with an "is_good" flag for trianing NN'''
    
    # Select training data with flag for good or bad data.
    good = select_good_sources(table).select(features).withColumn('is_good', lit(1))
    bad = select_bad_sources(table).select(features).withColumn('is_good', lit(0))
    
    factor = healpix_level_N(source_id = None, level = 6, constant = True)
    
    # Join data with a column for |SNR|
    df = good.union(bad)\
                    .withColumn('abs_SNR', 
                                f.abs(col('parallax_over_error')))\
                    .withColumn('hpx6', floor(col('source_id')/factor))
    print('DataBase with flags')
    
    return df

paragraphs.title: Drop Bad Pixels
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

# Total pixels = 49,152 (Currently 10410 good??)

def drop_bad_pixels(data, all_sources):
    '''drop good sources from HEALpix6 pixels that contain bad sources'''
    
    # Identify bad pixels
    # bad_pixels = set([int(i[0]) for i in df.filter(col('parallax_over_error') < -3.0)\
    #                   .select('hpx6').toPandas().values])
    
    bad_pixels = spark.sql(f'SELECT FLOOR(a.source_id/{factor}) as hpx6 \
    FROM {all_sources} as a \
    WHERE (a.parallax_over_error < - 3.5)').distinct()
                      
    # bad_pixels = data.filter(col('parallax_over_error') < -3.5).select('hpx6').distinct() # spark version of above

    # Drop data from pixels that contain bad datapoints
    # data = data.filter((col('is_good') == 0) | 
    #               ((col('is_good') == 1) & 
    #                 (~data.hpx6.isin(bad_pixels))))
    
    bad = data.filter((col('is_good') == 0))
    # Add bad.columns to ensure correct column order for join
    good = data.join(bad_pixels, 'hpx6', how = "left_anti")[bad.columns]
    
    df = good.union(bad)

    # N_good_pixels = data.select('hpx6').distinct()
    return df

df = with_flags(table = 'dcr_raw_sources', features = features)
df = drop_bad_pixels(df, all_sources = 'dcr_raw_sources')
df = df.cache()
df.createOrReplaceTempView('dcr_data')

paragraphs.title: Spacial Distribution
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
def spacialDistributionSubplot(class_val = 0, label = None, limit = None, labelCol = 'label', color = 'k', save = False):

    plt.figure(3, figsize = (16.18, 10.0))
    
    dat = spark.sql(f'SELECT b.is_good, a.ra, a.dec FROM gaia_source as a, \
                                                 dcr_training_sources as b \
                                                 WHERE a.source_id = b.source_id LIMIT {limit}')
    dat = dat.withColumn('raProj', (col('ra') - 180.0) * np.pi / 180.0)\
                .withColumn('decProj', (col('dec') * np.pi / 180.0))\
                    .select(['raProj', 'decProj', 'is_good'])\
                        .toPandas()
    
    print('data in Pandas')
    for i, value in enumerate(class_val):
        tmp = dat[dat['is_good'] == value]
        plt.subplot(1,2,i+1, projection='aitoff')
        plt.grid(True)
        plt.title(f'{label[i]}')
        plt.scatter(tmp['raProj'], tmp['decProj'], marker = '.', s = 1, c = color[i])
    if save:
        savefigs(save)
    plt.show()
    
spacialDistributionSubplot(class_val = [1,0], label = ['Good Sources', 'Bad Sources'], 
                    color = ['k', 'darkred'], limit = 10000, labelCol = 'is_good')

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Regimes:

### Low |SNR|
* |SNR| < 4.5 but training data omits data with |SNR| < 4.5 to prevent the imbalance in coverage of SNR-space in the good and bad training sets from impacting our classifications in the low-SNR regime.
* Does not include |SNR| as a feature.

### High |SNR|
* Uses the entire training set

msg.data:
Regimes:

Low |SNR|

  • |SNR| < 4.5 but training data omits data with |SNR| < 4.5 to prevent the imbalance in coverage of SNR-space in the good and bad training sets from impacting our classifications in the low-SNR regime.
  • Does not include |SNR| as a feature.

High |SNR|

  • Uses the entire training set

paragraphs.title: Return correct data for regime
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

def return_low_snr(df, features = '*'):
    '''Creates low SNR training dataset. (-3.5 < SNR < 4.5)
    This dataset does not include parallax over error as a training feature
    Counter intuitively, this dataset only includes data with |SNR| > 4.5.'''
    df = df.select(features)\
                .filter((col('abs_SNR') > 4.5) | (col('is_good') == 0))
    
#     print(f' Low SNR dataset contains {df.filter(df.is_good == 1).count()} \
# "good" data points and {df.filter(df.is_good == 0).count()} "bad" datapoints.')
    print('Low SNR dataset returned')
    return df

def return_high_snr(df, features = '*'):
    '''Creates high SNR training dataset. (|SNR| > 4.5)
    This dataset does include parallax over error as a training feature.'''
    
#     print(f'High SNR dataset contains {df.filter(df.is_good == 1).count()} \
# "good" data points and {df.filter(df.is_good == 0).count()} "bad" datapoints.')
    print('High SNR dataset returned')
    
    return df.select(features)

paragraphs.title: Split into Train and Test Data
Select Training Features

paragraphs.text:
%md

# Normalization

paragraphs.title: getScaler
Build the Model
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

def dataSparkML(df, regime, labelCol = 'labels', featuresCol = 'features', 
                normalise = False, scalerType = 'standard', save = False):
    '''get train and test dataset for input using pyspark.ml'''

    # Get data and label columns for the selected regime
    data  = get_training_data(df, regime = regime)
    train_features = select_training_features(data[0], regime = regime)
    N_features = len(train_features)
    # Assemble assember to merge features into DenseVector
    assembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols=train_features,
                                outputCol=featuresCol)
    
    
    train = assembler.transform(data[0])\
                .select(['source_id', featuresCol, labelCol])
    test  = assembler.transform(data[1])\
                .select(['source_id', featuresCol, labelCol])
    
    if normalise:
        # We rename featuresCol to maintain col name for later analysis
        model = getScalerModel(train.withColumnRenamed(featuresCol, 'inputFeatures'),
                               scalerType = scalerType, featuresCol = 'inputFeatures', 
                               outCol = featuresCol, save = save)
        
        # Normalise each dataset with the training data distributions
        train = normaliseData(train.withColumnRenamed(featuresCol, 'inputFeatures'), model)
        test  = normaliseData( test.withColumnRenamed(featuresCol, 'inputFeatures'), model)
        
        print(f'Training data = {train.count()} sources')
    
    return (train, test, N_features)

# train,test, N_features, model = dataSparkML(df, regime = 'low', labelCol = 'is_good', normalise = True)

paragraphs.title: MLlib_confusion_matrix
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark


import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pylab as plt
from collections import Counter

class MLlib_confusion_matrix():
    '''subclass to plot confusion matrix'''
    def __init__(self, df, labelCol = 'label', classes = None, normalize = True):
        self.df               = df
        self.getLabelCol      = labelCol
        self.grouped          = df.groupBy(labelCol, 'prediction').count().toPandas()
        self.matrix           = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        self.normMatrix       = self.getNormConfusionMatrix()
        self.confusion_matrix = self.confusionMatrix(classes, normalize)

    def __repr__(self) : return f"""Class for plotting confusion matrix {self.normMatrix}"""

    def getConfusionMatrix(self):
        '''returns confusion matrix based on values'''

        N_classes = len(set(self.grouped[self.getLabelCol]))
        matrix = np.empty((N_classes, N_classes))
        for i in range(N_classes):
            for j in range(N_classes):
                c = self.grouped[(self.grouped[self.getLabelCol] == i) & 
                                 (self.grouped.prediction == j)]['count'].values
                if len(c) == 0:
                    c = 0 
                matrix[i][j] =  c
        return matrix

    def getNormConfusionMatrix(self):
        '''returns confusion matrix based on values'''

        N_classes = len(set(self.grouped[self.getLabelCol]))
        matrix = np.empty((N_classes, N_classes))
        for i in range(N_classes):
            for j in range(N_classes):
                c = self.grouped[(self.grouped[self.getLabelCol] == i) & 
                        (self.grouped.prediction == j)]['count'].values\
                            /sum(self.grouped[(self.grouped[self.getLabelCol] == i)]['count'])
                if len(c) == 0:
                    c = 0 
                matrix[i][j] =  np.round(c , 4)
        return matrix
    
    def confusionMatrix(self, classes = None, normalize = True):
        '''prints rich version of confusion matrix'''

        if normalize: matrix = self.normMatrix
        else: matrix = self.matrix
        if classes == None:
            classes = range(len(matrix))

        N_classes = range(len(classes))
        plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (6,6)

        plt.imshow(matrix, cmap = 'Greens', alpha = 0.75)
        for i in N_classes: # Add values to max pooling
            for j in N_classes:
                text = plt.text(j, i, matrix[i][j],
                               ha="center", va="center", color="k", fontsize = 20)

        #Add thick line to matrix
        axis = plt.gca()
        axis.set_yticks(np.arange(-0.5, len(classes)-0.5, 1), minor='True')
        axis.set_xticks(np.arange(-0.5, len(classes)-0.5, 1), minor='True')
        axis.yaxis.grid(True, which='minor', color = 'k', lw = 2)
        axis.xaxis.grid(True, which='minor', color = 'k', lw = 2)
        plt.xticks(N_classes, classes, rotation =0, fontsize = 14)
        plt.yticks(N_classes, classes, rotation =0, fontsize = 14)
        plt.xlabel('Predicted Class', fontsize = 16)
        plt.ylabel('True Class', fontsize = 16)
        
        
class MLlibMultiClassEvaluator(MLlib_confusion_matrix):
    '''class to calculate parameters of NN performance for binary classification'''
    
    def __init__(self, df, labelCol = 'label'):
        self.df            = df
        self.getLabelCol   = labelCol
        self.show          = df.show
        # self.count         = df.count
        # self.shape         = (df.count(), len(df.columns))
        # self.grouped       = df.groupBy(labelCol, 'prediction').count().toPandas()
        self.matrix        = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        
    # def __len__(self)         : return self.df.count()
    # def __repr__(self)        : return f"""Evaluate ML performance for {len(self)} datapoints."""
    
    def getAnalysis(self):
        '''returns a pd.DataFrame for analysis'''
        data = self.df.select(self.getLabelCol,'probability', 'prediction').toPandas()
        for i in range(max(data[self.getLabelCol])+1):
            data[f'prob'] = [max(j) for j in data.probability]
        return data
    
    def getTruePositives(self, step = np.arange(0.0, 0.95, 0.01)):
        '''calculates how True Positives change by threshold'''
        conMat = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        data = self.getAnalysis()
        tp = {}
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            tp[cat] = []
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            for threshold in step:
                tmp = Counter(data[(data['prediction'] == data[self.getLabelCol]) & 
                                   (data[f'prob']>threshold)][self.getLabelCol])
                for cat in range(len(conMat)):
                    tp[cat].append(tmp[cat])
            return tp
        
        
    def getFalsePositives(self, step = np.arange(0.0, 0.95, 0.01)):
        '''calculates how True Positives change by threshold'''
        conMat = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        data = self.getAnalysis()
        fp = {}
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            fp[cat] = []
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            for threshold in step:
                tmp = Counter(data[(data['prediction'] != data[self.getLabelCol]) & 
                                   (data[f'prob']>threshold)].prediction)
                for cat in range(len(conMat)):
                    fp[cat].append(tmp[cat])
            return fp        
        
    def getFalseNegatives(self, step = np.arange(0.0, 0.95, 0.01)):
        '''calculates how False Positives change by threshold'''
        conMat = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        data = self.getAnalysis()
        fn = {}
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            fn[cat] = []
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            for threshold in step:
                tmp = Counter(data[(data['prediction'] != data[self.getLabelCol]) & 
                                   (data[f'prob']>threshold)][self.getLabelCol])
                for cat in range(len(conMat)):
                    fn[cat].append(tmp[cat])
            return fn
        
    def getPrecision(self, step = np.arange(0.0, 0.95, 0.01)):
        '''calculate precision'''
        precision = {}; true_positives = self.getTruePositives(step); 
        false_positives = self.getFalsePositives(step)
        conMat = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        precision = {}
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            precision[cat] = conMat[cat][cat]
            for cat in range(len(conMat)):
                precision[cat] = [tp / (tp+fp) for tp, fp in zip(true_positives[cat],false_positives[cat])]
        return precision
    
    def getRecall(self, step = np.arange(0.0, 0.95, 0.01)):
        '''calculate recall'''
        conMat = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        recall = {}; true_positives = self.getTruePositives(step); 
        false_negatives = self.getFalseNegatives(step)
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            recall[cat] = []
            for cat in range(len(conMat)):
                recall[cat] = [tp / (tp+fn) for tp, fn in zip(true_positives[cat],false_negatives[cat])]
        return recall
    
    
class plottingThreshold(MLlibMultiClassEvaluator):
    '''subclass of "threshold" for various plots of useful threshold parameters.'''
    
    def __repr__(self): return f"""Plotting software for 'threshold' objects"""
    def __init__(self, df, labelCol = 'label'):
        self.df            = df
        self.getLabelCol   = labelCol
        self.show          = df.show
        # self.count         = df.count
        # self.shape         = (df.count(), len(df.columns))
        self.grouped       = df.groupBy(labelCol, 'prediction').count().toPandas()
        self.matrix        = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        
        
    def getAxes(self,ax):
        if ax == None:
            ax = plt.subplot(111)
        return ax

    def plot_true_positives(self, ax = None, step = np.arange(0.0, 0.95, 0.01), normalize = True, legend = True):
        ax = self.getAxes(ax); true_positives = self.getTruePositives(step); 
        conMat = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            if normalize == True:
                y = [i/max(true_positives[cat]) for i in true_positives[cat]]
                ax.set_ylabel('Fraction of Total True Positives -->')
            else:
                y = [i/len(self.data[self.data.true_label == cat]) for i in true_positives[cat]]
                ax.set_ylabel('True Positives -->')
            ax.plot(step, y, label = cat)
        if legend:
            ax.legend()
        ax.grid('on')
        ax.set_xlabel('Threshold')

    def plot_false_positives(self, ax = None, step = np.arange(0.0, 0.95, 0.01), legend = True):
        ax = self.getAxes(ax); false_positives = self.getFalsePositives(step)
        conMat = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            if max(false_positives[cat]) != 0:
                y = [i/max(false_positives[cat]) for i in false_positives[cat]]
            else: y = [i for i in false_positives[cat]]
            ax.plot(step, y, label = cat)
        if legend:
            ax.legend()
        ax.grid('on')
        ax.set_xlabel('Threshold')
        ax.set_ylabel('<-- Fraction of Total False Positives')

    def plot_precision(self, ax = None, step = np.arange(0.0, 0.95, 0.01), legend = True):
        ax = self.getAxes(ax); precision = self.getPrecision(step)
        conMat = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            y = precision[cat]
            ax.plot(step, y, label = cat)
        if legend:
            ax.legend()
        ax.grid('on')
        ax.set_xlabel('Threshold')
        ax.set_ylabel('Precision -->')

    def plot_recall(self, ax = None, step = np.arange(0.0, 0.95, 0.01), legend = True):
        ax = self.getAxes(ax); recall = self.getRecall(step)
        conMat = self.getConfusionMatrix()
        for cat in range(len(conMat)):
            y = recall[cat]
            ax.plot(step, y, label = cat)
        if legend:
            ax.legend()
        ax.grid('on')
        ax.set_xlabel('Threshold')
        ax.set_ylabel('Recall -->')
        

    def threshold_subplots(self, step = np.arange(0.0, 0.95, 0.01), figsize=(15, 8)):
        import matplotlib.gridspec as gridspec
        fig = plt.figure(figsize = figsize)
        gs = gridspec.GridSpec(ncols=2, nrows=2, figure=fig)
        ax1 = fig.add_subplot(gs[0, 0])
        ax2 = fig.add_subplot(gs[0, 1])
        ax3 = fig.add_subplot(gs[1, 0])
        ax4 = fig.add_subplot(gs[1, 1])

        axs = [ax1, ax2, ax3, ax4]
        self.plot_precision      (ax = axs[0], step = step, legend = False)
        self.plot_recall         (ax = axs[1], step = step, legend = False)
        self.plot_true_positives (ax = axs[2], step = step, legend = True )
        self.plot_false_positives(ax = axs[3], step = step, legend = True )
        plt.tight_layout()

%spark.pyspark
sqlContext.clearCache()

paragraphs.title: Train the model
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

def nnTrainModel(df, regime, labelCol = 'label',
                 featuresCol = 'features',
                 scalerType = 'standard', save = False, 
                 normalise = False):
    '''trains a neural network using sparkML'''
    
    # get train, test and N_features 
    train, test, \
        N_features = dataSparkML(df = df, regime = regime, labelCol = labelCol, 
                                 normalise = normalise, featuresCol = featuresCol,
                                 save = save, scalerType = scalerType)
    
    # specify layers for the neural network:
    layers = [N_features, 64, 64, 64, 64, 2]

    # create the trainer and set its parameters
    trainer = MultilayerPerceptronClassifier(maxIter=100, layers=layers, blockSize=128, seed=42)\
                    .setLabelCol(labelCol)
    
    print(trainer)

    # train the model
    model = trainer.fit(train)
    if save:
        model.save(f'{save}/MultilayerPerceptronClassifier/')
    return train, test, model


train, test, model = nnTrainModel(df = df, regime = 'high', normalise = True,
                                  labelCol = 'is_good', scalerType = 'standard',
                                  save = '{user_home}/ML_cuts/highSNR')
                                  
# Low training sources: 5,878,144 for <1 kpc
# High training sources: XX for <3 kpc

paragraphs.title: Evaluate Model
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

def evaluateModel(model, df, labelCol = 'label', evaluate = False,
                  normalise = True,
                  step = np.arange(0.5, 0.99, 0.025)):
    '''Apply a NN to new data, with the option to evaluate if test dataset'''
    
    # compute accuracy on the test set
    result = model.transform(df)
    predictionAndLabels = result.select("prediction", 'is_good')
    evaluator = MulticlassClassificationEvaluator(metricName="accuracy").setLabelCol(labelCol)
#     print("Test set accuracy = " + str(evaluator.evaluate(predictionAndLabels)))
    
    if evaluate:
        # Call MLlib_confusion_matrix class to plot confusion matrix
        res = MLlib_confusion_matrix(result, labelCol = labelCol)
        res.confusionMatrix(classes = ['Bad', 'Good'], normalize = True)
        
        # Call plottingThreshold to explore the effect of Thresholding
        plottingThreshold(result, labelCol = labelCol)\
            .threshold_subplots(step = step)

    return result

result = evaluateModel(model = model, df = test, normalise = True,  evaluate = True, 
                      labelCol = 'is_good')

%spark.pyspark

result.createOrReplaceTempView('ML_res')

paragraphs.title: CAMD_2
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
def CAMD(passbands, catalogue, classes, colors = ['k', 'darkred', 'darkblue'], 
         ms = 1, labels = None, limit = 10000):
    '''Plot an observational Hertzsprung-Russell diagram (aka colour / absolute magnitude diagram)
    for the unclassified sample to show the problem,
    include the photometric consistency filter to show the problem is astrometric in addition to photometric '''
    
    fig = plt.figure(0, figsize = (9.0, 9.0))
    c = -1
    for i in classes:
        c+=1
        if type(ms) == list:
            s = ms[c]
        else: s = ms
        if type(labels) == type(None):
            label = i
        else: label = labels[c]
        unclassified_camd_df = spark.sql(f'SELECT b.prediction , a.source_id,\
                                         a.phot_{passbands[0]}_mean_mag + 5.0*LOG10(a.parallax/100.0) \
                                         AS m_{passbands[0]}, {passbands[1]} FROM {catalogue} as a, \
                                         {"ML_res"} as b \
                                         WHERE a.source_id = b.source_id AND parallax > 0 \
                                         LIMIT {limit}')
        
        unclassified_camd_df = unclassified_camd_df.filter(col('prediction') == c)
        x = unclassified_camd_df.select('g_rp').toPandas()['g_rp'][:limit]
        y = unclassified_camd_df.select('m_g').toPandas()['m_g'][:limit]
        plt.scatter(x, y, marker = '.', s = ms, label = label, color = colors[c])
    plt.ylim(21.0, -3.0)
    plt.xlim(0, 3.5)
    plt.ylabel('Stellar brightness (absolute G magnitude) -->', fontsize = 16)
    plt.xlabel('<-- Stellar temperature (G - RP magnitude)', fontsize = 16)
    lgnd = plt.legend(fontsize = 12)
    for i in range(len(classes)):
        lgnd.legendHandles[i]._sizes = [55]

# CAMD(passbands = ['g', 'g_rp'], catalogue = 'dcr_raw_sources', 
#      colors = ['grey', 'green'], classes = ['Bad','Good'], ms = 1, limit = 5000)

%spark.pyspark
# test.filter(col('is_good') == 0).count(), test.count()

%spark.pyspark
def CAMD(passbands, catalogue, classes, colors = ['k', 'darkred', 'darkblue'], 
         ms = 1, labels = None, limit = 10000):
    '''Plot an observational Hertzsprung-Russell diagram (aka colour / absolute magnitude diagram)
    for the unclassified sample to show the problem,
    include the photometric consistency filter to show the problem is astrometric in addition to photometric '''
    
    fig = plt.figure(0, figsize = (9.0, 9.0))
    c = -1
    
    unclassified_camd_df = spark.sql(f'SELECT b.prediction , a.source_id,\
                                         a.phot_{passbands[0]}_mean_mag + 5.0*LOG10(a.parallax/100.0) \
                                         AS m_{passbands[0]}, {passbands[1]} FROM {catalogue} as a, \
                                         {"ML_res"} as b \
                                         WHERE a.source_id = b.source_id \
                                         LIMIT {limit}')
    for i in classes:
        c+=1
        if type(ms) == list:
            s = ms[c]
        else: s = ms
        if type(labels) == type(None):
            label = i
        else: label = labels[c]
        
        tmp = unclassified_camd_df.filter(col('prediction') == c)
        tmp = tmp.select(['g_rp', 'm_g']).toPandas()
        plt.scatter(tmp['g_rp'], tmp['m_g'], marker = '.', s = ms, label = label, color = colors[c])
    plt.ylim(21.0, -3.0)
    plt.xlim(0, 3.5)
    plt.ylabel('Stellar brightness (absolute G magnitude) -->', fontsize = 16)
    plt.xlabel('<-- Stellar temperature (G - RP magnitude)', fontsize = 16)
    lgnd = plt.legend(fontsize = 12)
    for i in range(len(classes)):
        lgnd.legendHandles[i]._sizes = [55]
        
# CAMD(passbands = ['g', 'g_rp'], catalogue = 'dcr_raw_sources', 
#      colors = ['grey', 'green'], classes = ['Bad','Good'], ms = 1, limit = 5000)

msg.data: Evalute all sources from raw_sources_cached using the given model

paragraphs.title: Load models
Evaluate Unlabelled Data
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

def selectRegime(df, regime = 'high'):
    if 'high' in regime:
        return df.filter(col('abs_SNR') > 4.5)
    if 'low' in regime:
        return df.filter(col('abs_SNR') < 4.5)


def select_unlabelled_data(table, regime, filename, featuresCol = 'features', 
                           normalise = False, scalerType = 'standard'):
    '''selects full table to apply the trained model'''
    
    features = getFeatures(withPhotometric = True)
    # Get unlabelled data
    df = spark.sql(f'SELECT a.*, a.phot_g_mean_mag + 5.0*LOG10(a.parallax/100.0) \
                                         AS m_g, a.g_rp FROM {table} as a')
    df = df.select(features).withColumn('abs_SNR', 
                        f.abs(col('parallax_over_error')))
    
    # Get data that fits the regime abs_SNR parameters
    df = selectRegime(df = df, regime = regime)
    features = select_training_features(df, regime = regime)
    
    # Assemble training features into DenseVector
    assembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols=features,
                                outputCol=featuresCol)
    df = assembler.transform(df)\
                .select(['source_id', 'm_g', 'g_rp', featuresCol])
    
    if normalise:
        # Scale the independent test data with a loaded scaler
        scaler = loadScaler(f'{filename}/{scalerType}_normalisation_model', scalerType = scalerType)
        df = normaliseData(df.withColumnRenamed(featuresCol, 'inputFeatures'), model = scaler)
        
    # Evaluate data with trained model
    nnModelRead = nnLoadModel(filepath = f'{filename}/MultilayerPerceptronClassifier')
    df = evaluateModel(nnModel = nnModelRead, df = df, normalise = True,  evaluate = False, 
                       labelCol = 'is_good')
    return df

# new = select_unlabelled_data(table = 'edr3_sources', regime = 'high', filename = 'temp/',
#                       normalise = True, scalerType = 'standard')

paragraphs.title: Spatial Plots
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
def spatialDistributionSubplot(catalogue, resCat, class_val = 0, label = None, color = 'k', save = False):

    plt.figure(3, figsize = (16.18, 10.0))
    
    for i, value in enumerate(class_val):
        plt.subplot(1,2,i+1, projection='aitoff')
        plt.grid(True)

        df = spark.sql(f'SELECT b.prediction , b.source_id,\
                                                 a.ra, a.dec FROM {catalogue} as a, \
                                                 {resCat} as b \
                                                 WHERE a.source_id = b.source_id \
                                                 AND b.prediction = {class_val[i]}')
        print(df.count())
        x = list((df.select('ra').toPandas()['ra'] - 180.0) * np.pi / 180.0)
        y = list( df.select('dec').toPandas()['dec'] * np.pi / 180.0)
        plt.title(f'{label[i]}')
        plt.scatter(x, y, marker = '.', s = 1, c = color[i])
    if save:
        savefigs(save)
    plt.show()
    
# spatialDistributionSubplot(catalogue = 'edr3_sources', resCat = 'dcr_ML_res', 
#                     class_val = [1,0], label = ['Good Sources', 'Bad Sources'], 
#                     color = ['k', 'darkred'])
